medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: Right lumbosacral radiculopathy secondary to lumbar spondylolysis. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: Right lumbosacral radiculopathy secondary to lumbar spondylolysis. OPERATION PERFORMED: 1. Right L4 and L5 transpedicular decompression of distal right L4 and L5 nerve roots. 2. Right L4-L5 and right L5-S1 laminotomies, medial facetectomies, and foraminotomies, decompression of right L5 and S1 nerve roots. 3. Right L4-S1 posterolateral fusion with local bone graft. 4. Left L4 through S1 segmental pedicle screw instrumentation. 5. Preparation harvesting of local bone graft. ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal. PREPARATION: Povidone-iodine. INDICATION: This is a gentleman with right-sided lumbosacral radiculopathy, MRI disclosed and lateral recess stenosis at the L4-5, L5-S1 foraminal narrowing in L4 and L5 roots. The patient was felt to be a candidate for decompression stabilization pulling distraction between the screws to relieve radicular pain. The patient understood major risks and complications such as death and paralysis seemingly rare, main concern is a 10 to 15% of failure rate to respond to surgery for which further surgery may or may not be indicated, small risk of wound infection, spinal fluid leak. The patient is understanding and agreed to proceed and signed the consent. PROCEDURE: The patient was brought to the operating room, peripheral venous lines were placed. General anesthesia was induced. The patient was intubated. Foley catheter was in place. The patient laid prone onto the OSI table using 6-post, pressure points were carefully padded; the back was shaved, sterilely prepped and draped. A previous incision was infiltrated with local and incised with a scalpel. The posterior spine on the right side was exposed in routine fashion along with transverse processes in L4-L5 in the sacral ala. Laminotomies were then performed at L4-L5 and L5-S1 in a similar fashion using Midas Rex drill with AM8 bit, inferior portion of lamina below and superior portion of lamina above, and the medial facet was drilled down to the thin shelf of bone. The thin shelf of bone along the ligamentum flavum moved in a piecemeal fashion with 2 and 3 mm Kerrison, bone was harvested throughout to be used for bone grafting. The L5 and S1 roots were completely unroofed in the lateral recess working lateral to the markedly hypertrophied facet joints. Transpedicular approaches were carried out for both L4 and L5 roots working lateral to medial and medial to lateral with foraminotomies, L4-L5 roots were extensively decompressed. Pars interarticularis were maintained. Using angled 2-mm Kerrisons hypertrophied ligamentum flavum, the superior facet of S1 and L5 was resected increasing the dimensions for the foramen passed lateral to medial and medial to lateral without further compromise. Pedicle screws were placed L4-L5 and S1 on the right side. Initial hole began with Midas Rex drill, deepened with a gear shift and with 4.5 mm tap, palpating with pedicle probe. It showed no penetration outside the pedicle vertebral body. At L4-L5 5.5 x 45 mm screws were placed and at S1 5.5 x 40 mm screw was placed. Good bone purchase was obtained. Gelfoam was placed over the roots laterally, corticated transverse processes lateral facet joints were prepared, small infuse sponge was placed posterolaterally on the right side, then the local bone graft from L4 to S1. Traction was applied between the L4-L5, L5-S1 screws locking notes were tightened out, heads were rotated fractured off about 2-3 mm traction were applied at each side, further opening the foramen for the exiting roots. Prior to placement of BMP, the wound was irrigated with antibiotic irrigation. Medium Hemovac drain was placed in the depth of wound, brought out through a separate stab incision. Deep fascia was closed with #1 Vicryl, subcutaneous fascia with #1 Vicryl, and subcuticular with 2-0 Vicryl. Skin was stapled. The drain was sutured in place with 2-0 Vicryl and connected to closed drain system. The patient was laid supine on the bed, extubated, and taken to recovery room in satisfactory condition. The patient tolerated the procedure well without apparent complication. Final sponge and needle counts are correct. Estimated blood loss 600 mL. The patient received 200 mL of cell saver blood back.
layman:
**Pre‑operative diagnosis:**  
Right‑sided lower back and leg pain caused by a nerve problem at the right side of the lower spine, due to a small crack in the bone (spondylolysis) at the L4‑L5 level.

**Post‑operative diagnosis:**  
Same as before – right‑sided lower back and leg pain from the crack at L4‑L5.

**Operation performed:**  
1. Removed bone to relieve pressure on the right L4 and L5 nerve roots.  
2. Cut into the back bones (laminotomies) at L4‑L5 and L5‑S1, removed part of the joint surfaces (facetectomies) and widened the openings (foraminotomies) to free the right L5 and S1 nerves.  
3. Joined the right L4‑S1 bones with a fusion using the patient’s own bone.  
4. Placed screws into the left L4‑S1 bones for support.  
5. Took bone from the back to use for the fusion.

**Anesthesia:**  
General anesthesia with a breathing tube.

**Preparation:**  
The back was cleaned with povidone‑iodine.

**Indication for surgery:**  
The patient had right‑sided leg pain and MRI showed narrowing of the space where the nerves exit at L4‑5 and L5‑S1. Surgery was chosen to decompress the nerves and stabilize the spine. The patient was told about the small risks of death, paralysis, infection, fluid leak, and that 10‑15 % of people may not feel better and might need more surgery. The patient understood and signed the consent form.

**Procedure:**  
The patient was taken to the operating room, IV lines were placed, and general anesthesia was started. A breathing tube was inserted and a urinary catheter was put in. The patient lay face‑down on a special table; pressure points were padded. The back was shaved, cleaned, and covered with sterile drapes. The old incision was numbed with local anesthetic and cut open. The right side of the back was exposed, including the L4‑L5 and L5‑S1 bones. Small cuts (laminotomies) were made at L4‑L5 and L5‑S1 with a drill and small bone saws. Bone was removed from the ligament and the joint surfaces to widen the nerve openings. The L5 and S1 nerves were fully exposed. The L4 and L5 nerves were also freed from bone. The joint cracks were left intact. The bone from the ligament was removed to use for the fusion.  

Screws were placed into the right L4‑L5 and S1 bones. The holes were drilled, tapped, and the screws were inserted, checking that they stayed inside the bone. The screws were 5.5 mm wide and 45 mm long at L4‑L5, and 5.5 mm wide and 40 mm long at S1. The screws had good purchase. Gel foam was placed over the nerves. The outer bone surfaces were prepared, and a small sponge was put on the right side. The patient’s own bone from L4‑S1 was placed over the area. The screws were pulled slightly to stretch the spine and open the nerve openings more. The wound was washed with antibiotic solution. A drain was put in the deep part of the wound and brought out through a small cut. The deep fascia, subcutaneous tissue, and skin were closed with stitches and staples. The drain was tied in place and connected to a closed system. The patient was turned onto his back, taken off the breathing tube, and sent to recovery in good condition. The procedure went well with no obvious problems. The final counts of sponges and needles were correct. Blood loss was about 600 mL, and 200 mL of the patient’s own blood was returned to him.
